message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Robotics: A Survey of Real-World Successes
Paper Abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL), particularly its combination with deep neural networks referred to as deep RL (DRL), has shown tremendous promise across a wide range of applications, suggesting its potential for enabling the development of sophisticated robotic behaviors. Robotics problems, however, pose fundamental difficulties for the application of RL, stemming from the complexity and cost of interacting with the physical world. These challenges notwithstanding, recent advances have enabled DRL to succeed at some real-world robotic tasks. However, state-of-the-art DRL solutions’ maturity varies significantly across robotic applications. In this talk, I will review the current progress of DRL in real-world robotic applications based on our recent survey paper (with Tang, Abbatematteo, Hu, Chandra, and Martı́n-Martı́n), with a particular focus on evaluating the real-world successes achieved with DRL in realizing several key robotic competencies, including locomotion, navigation, stationary manipulation, mobile manipulation, human-robot interaction, and multi-robot interaction. The analysis aims to identify the key factors underlying those exciting successes, reveal underexplored areas, and provide an overall characterization of the status of DRL in robotics. I will also highlight several important avenues for future work, emphasizing the need for stable and sample-efficient real-world RL paradigms, holistic approaches for discovering and integrating various competencies to tackle complex long-horizon, open-world tasks, and principled development and evaluation procedures. The talk is designed to offer insights for RL practitioners and roboticists toward harnessing RL’s power to create generally capable real-world robotic systems.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Robotics Overview

Based on the search results, here's what you should know about robotics:

### Definition and Scope

Robotics is the interdisciplinary study and practice of the design, construction, operation, and use of robots.(no content)A robot is a machine—especially one programmable by a computer—capable of carrying out a complex series of actions automatically.

### Key Components

Within mechanical engineering, robotics is the design and construction of the physical structures of robots, while in computer science, robotics focuses on robotic automation algorithms. Generally, robot systems involve three main aspects:

1. **Mechanical construction** - the frame or form designed to accomplish a specific task
2. **Electrical components** - power and control systems for the machinery
3. **Software** - programs that determine how and when a robot performs actions

### Types and Applications

The field includes diverse robot designs and applications:

- Soft robotics is a subfield of robotics that concerns the design, control, and fabrication of robots composed of compliant materials, instead of rigid links.

- A robotic arm is a type of mechanical arm, usually programmable, with similar functions to a human arm.

- A hexapod robot is a mechanical vehicle that walks on six legs.

### Educational Programs

In April 2018, VEX Robotics Competition was named the largest robotics competition in the world by Guinness World Records.

## Neural Networks - Search Results

I've performed a web search for "Neural Networks" and found comprehensive information. Here's an overview of what neural networks are:

### Definition and Basic Structure

A neural network consists of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, which loosely model the neurons in the brain.(no content)Neurons in an artificial neural network are usually arranged into layers, with information passing from the first layer (the input layer) through one or more intermediate layers (the hidden layers) to the final layer (the output layer).

### Applications

Neural networks are used to solve problems in artificial intelligence, and have thereby found applications in many disciplines, including predictive modeling, adaptive control, facial recognition, handwriting recognition, general game playing, and generative AI.

### How They Learn

Neural networks are typically trained through empirical risk minimization, which is based on the idea of optimizing the network's parameters to minimize the difference, or empirical risk, between the predicted output and the actual target values in a given dataset.(no content)Gradient-based methods such as backpropagation are usually used to estimate the parameters of the network.

### Types of Neural Networks

The search results mention several specialized types including:
- Convolutional neural networks (CNNs), a type of feedforward neural network that learns features via filter optimization, which has been applied to process and make predictions from many different types of data including text, images and audio.
- Graph neural networks (GNN) are specialized artificial neural networks that are designed for tasks whose inputs are graphs.

## Deep Reinforcement Learning

Deep reinforcement learning (deep RL) is a subfield of machine learning that combines reinforcement learning (RL) and deep learning.(no content)RL considers the problem of a computational agent learning to make decisions by trial and error.

### How It Works

Deep RL incorporates deep learning into the solution, allowing agents to make decisions from unstructured input data without manual engineering of the state space.(no content)Deep RL algorithms are able to take in very large inputs (e.g. every pixel rendered to the screen in a video game) and decide what actions to perform to optimize an objective (e.g. maximizing the game score).

### Applications

Deep reinforcement learning has been used for a diverse set of applications including but not limited to robotics, video games, natural language processing, computer vision, education, transportation, finance and healthcare.(no content)In the past decade, deep RL has achieved remarkable results on a range of problems, from single and multiplayer games such as Go, Atari Games, and Dota 2 to robotics. Specific examples include AlphaGo, a computer program trained with deep RL to play Go, which became the first computer Go program to beat a human professional Go player without handicap on a full-sized 19×19 board in 2015.

### Approaches

There is a distinction between model-based and model-free reinforcement learning, which refers to whether the algorithm attempts to learn a forward model of the environment dynamics.

Web search results for query: "Navigation robotics"

Links: [{"title":"Robot navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_navigation"},{"title":"Robotic magnetic navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_magnetic_navigation"},{"title":"Robotic mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_mapping"},{"title":"Autonomous navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_navigation"},{"title":"Sea Machines Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sea_Machines_Robotics"},{"title":"Evolution Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_Robotics"},{"title":"Simultaneous localization and mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simultaneous_localization_and_mapping"},{"title":"Mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_robot"},{"title":"Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics"},{"title":"Silvio Savarese - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silvio_Savarese"}]

Here are the key results from the web search for "Navigation robotics":

## Definition and Overview

Robot navigation refers to the robot's ability to determine its own position in its frame of reference and then to plan a path towards some goal location.(no content)To navigate in its environment, the robot or any other mobility device requires a map of the environment and the ability to interpret that representation.

## Key Technologies and Methods

Several important navigation approaches are used in robotics:

- **SLAM (Simultaneous Localization and Mapping)**: SLAM is the computational problem of constructing or updating a map of an unknown environment while simultaneously keeping track of an agent's location within it.

- **Vision-Based Navigation**: Vision-based navigation uses computer vision algorithms and optical sensors, including laser-based range finders and photometric cameras, to extract visual features required for localization in the surrounding environment.

- **Guided Navigation**: Guidance can be done by burying inductive loops or magnets in the floor, painting lines on the floor, or placing beacons and markers, with such Automated Guided Vehicles (AGVs) used in industrial scenarios for transportation tasks.

## Types of Mobile Robots

Autonomous mobile robots (AMR) are capable of navigating an uncontrolled environment without the need for physical or electro-mechanical guidance devices.(no content)Hospitals have been using autonomous mobile robots to move materials for many years, and warehouses have installed mobile robotic systems to efficiently move materials from stocking shelves to order fulfillment zones.

Links: [{"title":"Category:Robotic manipulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Robotic_manipulation"},{"title":"Manipulator (device) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manipulator_(device)"},{"title":"Mobile manipulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_manipulator"},{"title":"Matthew T. Mason - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matthew_T._Mason"},{"title":"Roboy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roboy"},{"title":"Nautile - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nautile"},{"title":"Contact region - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contact_region"},{"title":"Schoenflies displacement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schoenflies_displacement"},{"title":"Kanguera - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kanguera"},{"title":"Talk:Euclidean group - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Euclidean_group"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of manipulation robotics:

## Definition

In robotics, a manipulator is a device used to manipulate materials without direct physical contact by the operator.

## Types of Manipulators

There are several types of robotic manipulators:
- Parallel manipulator – articulated robot or manipulator based on a number of kinematic chains, actuators and joints, in parallel.
- Serial manipulator – articulated robot or manipulator with a single series kinematic chain of actuators.
- Remote manipulator – manipulator under direct human control, often used for work with hazardous materials.

## Mobile Manipulation

A mobile manipulator is a robot system built from a robotic manipulator arm mounted on a mobile platform. A mobile robotic system combines the mobility offered by a mobile platform and dexterity offered by the manipulator.(no content)Mobile manipulators, either autonomous or remote operated, are used in many areas, such as space exploration, military operations, home care and health care.

## Industrial Applications

Many robotic manipulators, including some with parallel kinematic architecture, are used in industry for applications ranging from the manufacture of electronics to food processing and packaging industry.

## Grasping and Control

A Contact Region is a concept in robotics which describes the region between an object and a robot's end effector. This is used in object manipulation planning, and with the addition of sensors built into the manipulation system, can be used to produce a surface map or contact model of the object being grasped.

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about Multi-Robot Systems:

## Overview

Multi-robot systems represent an important area of robotics research and application. Swarm robotics is an approach to the coordination of multiple robots as a system which consist of large numbers of mostly simple physical robots.

## Key Characteristics

Swarm robotics is the study of how to design independent systems of robots without centralized control, where the emerging swarming behavior of robotic swarms is created through the interactions between individual robots and the environment.(no content)The design of swarm robotics systems is guided by swarm intelligence principles, which promote fault tolerance, scalability, and flexibility.

## Principles

Multi-robot systems typically operate on several key principles:
- Robots are autonomous
- Robots do not exploit centralized swarm control or global knowledge
- Robots cooperate with each other to accomplish the given task

## Challenges

Scaling robot systems raises thorny issues in coordination, safety, and communication, where in multi-agent navigation, challenges like deadlocks, selfish behaviors, and sample inefficiencies emerge.

## Applications

The search results indicate various applications exist, including search and retrieval tasks, manufacturing, and coordinated problem-solving inspired by natural systems like ant colonies and bee swarms.

Web search results for query: "Locomotion"

Links: [{"title":"The Loco-Motion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Loco-Motion"},{"title":"Locomotion Museum - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Locomotion_Museum"},{"title":"Chris Sawyer's Locomotion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Sawyer's_Locomotion"},{"title":"Robot locomotion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_locomotion"},{"title":"Rotating locomotion in living systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rotating_locomotion_in_living_systems"},{"title":"Undulatory locomotion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Undulatory_locomotion"},{"title":"Animal locomotion on the water surface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal_locomotion_on_the_water_surface"},{"title":"Locomotion No. 1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Locomotion_No._1"},{"title":"Locomotion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Locomotion"},{"title":"Locomotion (TV channel) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Locomotion_(TV_channel)"}]

Based on the web search results, here's what "Locomotion" can refer to:

## General Definition
Locomotion means the act or ability of something to transport or move itself from place to place.

## Specific Uses

**Music**: "The Loco-Motion" (or "Locomotion") is a pop song written by American songwriters Gerry Goffin and Carole King.(no content)The song is especially notable for making three appearances in the American top 3, each in a different decade: in 1962 by Little Eva (U.S. No. 1); in 1974 by Grand Funk Railroad (also U.S. No. 1); and in 1988 by Kylie Minogue (U.S. No. 3).

**Museum**: Locomotion, previously known as Locomotion the National Railway Museum at Shildon, is a railway museum in Shildon, County Durham, England.

**Video Game**: Chris Sawyer's Locomotion is a video game designed and programmed by independent game developer Chris Sawyer, and published by Atari Interactive in September 2004.

**Historical Steam Locomotive**: Locomotion No. 1 is an early steam locomotive that was built in 1825 by the pioneering railway engineers George and Robert Stephenson and became the first steam locomotive to haul a passenger-carrying train on a public railway, the Stockton and Darlington Railway.

**Television Channel**: Locomotion was a Latin American cable channel dedicated to anime and animated shows targeting primarily an 18–34 audience, broadcasting movies, TV series and shorts.

Links: [{"title":"Human–robot interaction","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human–robot_interaction"},{"title":"Human–robot collaboration","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human–robot_collaboration"},{"title":"International Conference on Human–Robot Interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Human-Robot_Interaction"},{"title":"Talk:Human–robot interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Human-robot_interaction"},{"title":"Cog (project) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cog_(project)"},{"title":"Julie Carpenter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Julie_Carpenter"},{"title":"Android science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Android_science"},{"title":"Hatice Gunes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hatice_Gunes"},{"title":"Thomas B. Sheridan - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_B._Sheridan"},{"title":"hitchBOT - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HitchBOT"}]

I've successfully retrieved search results about Human-Robot Interaction (HRI). Here's an overview of what I found:

## Definition and Scope

Human–robot interaction (HRI) is the study of interactions between humans and robots.(no content)Human–robot interaction is a multidisciplinary field with contributions from human–computer interaction, artificial intelligence, robotics, natural language processing, design, psychology and philosophy.

## Key Applications and Goals

Goals in HRI range from industrial manufacturing through Cobots, medical technology through rehabilitation, autism intervention, and elder care devices, entertainment, human augmentation, and other areas. Industrial applications of human-robot collaboration involve Collaborative Robots, or cobots, that physically interact with humans in a shared workspace to complete tasks such as collaborative manipulation or object handovers.

## Safety and Autonomy

Generally human–robot interaction prioritizes the safety of humans that interact with potentially dangerous robotics equipment.(no content)Although initially robots in the human–robot interaction field required some human intervention to function, research has expanded this to the extent that fully autonomous systems are now far more common than in the early 2000s.

## Research Approaches

The search results also include information on specific research areas like physical human–robot interaction (pHRI), which focuses on both device design for safe interaction and algorithmic approaches for fluent interactions. Additionally, Android science is an interdisciplinary framework for studying human interaction and cognition based on the premise that a very humanlike robot (that is, an android) can elicit human-directed social responses in human beings.

Human-Robot Interaction remains an active and growing field with applications across healthcare, manufacturing, entertainment, and service industries.

## Research Approaches

The search results also include information on specific research areas like physical human–robot interaction (pHRI), which focuses on both device design for safe interaction and algorithmic approaches for fluent interactions. Additionally, Android science is an interdisciplinary framework for studying human interaction and cognition based on the premise that a very humanlike robot (that is, an android) can elicit human-directed social responses in human beings.

Human-Robot Interaction remains an active and growing field with applications across healthcare, manufacturing, entertainment, and service industries.

Web search results for query: "Robot locomotion"

Links: [{"title":"Robot locomotion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_locomotion"},{"title":"Legged robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legged_robot"},{"title":"Outline of robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_robotics"},{"title":"Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics"},{"title":"Walking vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walking_vehicle"},{"title":"Mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_robot"},{"title":"Whegs - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whegs"},{"title":"Bio-inspired robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bio-inspired_robotics"},{"title":"Hexapod (robotics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hexapod_(robotics)"},{"title":"Robot control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_control"}]

Here's what I found about robot locomotion:

## Overview

Robot locomotion is the collective name for the various methods that robots use to transport themselves from place to place.

## Main Types of Locomotion

**Wheeled Robots:** Wheeled robots are typically quite energy efficient and simple to control.(no content)In terms of energy efficiency on hard, flat surfaces, wheeled robots are the most efficient because an ideal, non-deformable rolling wheel loses no energy.

**Legged Robots:** Legged robots use articulated limbs, such as leg mechanisms, to provide locomotion and are more versatile than wheeled robots and can traverse many different terrains, though these advantages require increased complexity and power consumption. Common types include:
- Bipedal robots exhibit bipedal motion and face two primary problems: stability control (balance) and motion control, with stability control being particularly difficult for bipedal systems.
- Quadrupedal robots exhibit quadrupedal motion and benefit from increased stability over bipedal robots, especially during movement.
- Hexapod robots are based on insect locomotion and multiple legs allow several different gaits, even if a leg is damaged.

**Snake Robots:** Mimicking the way real snakes move, these robots can navigate very confined spaces, meaning they may one day be used to search for people trapped in collapsed buildings.

**Whegs:** Whegs are mechanisms for robot locomotion that use a strategy combining the simplicity of the wheel with the obstacle-clearing advantages of the foot.

**Underwater Robots:** Fish can achieve a propulsive efficiency greater than 90% when swimming and can accelerate and maneuver far better than any man-made boat, so many researchers studying underwater robots would like to copy this type of locomotion.

I found relevant Wikipedia information about human-robot interaction. Here's what the search returned:

## Overview

Human robot interaction is a study of interactions between humans and robots. The ACM/IEEE International Conference on Human-Robot Interaction (HRI) focuses on human-robot interaction with roots in robotics, psychology, cognitive science, human computer interaction (HCI), human factors, artificial intelligence, organizational behavior, anthropology, and other fields.

## Applications and Goals

Goals in HRI range from industrial manufacturing through Cobots, medical technology through rehabilitation, autism intervention, and elder care devices, entertainment, human augmentation.

## Types of Robots

Robots in the human–robot interaction field are not limited to human-like robots: Paro and Kismet are both robots designed to elicit emotional response from humans, and so fall into the category of human–robot interaction.

## Safety Considerations

Generally human–robot interaction prioritizes the safety of humans that interact with potentially dangerous robotics equipment. Safety zones use technologies such as lidar to detect human presence or physical barriers to protect humans by preventing any contact between machine and operator.

You can access the full Wikipedia article on human-robot interaction at: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human–robot_interaction

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! The analysis is complete and validation has passed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Survey

**Key Findings:**

This paper is a **survey** that reviews the current state of deep reinforcement learning (DRL) in real-world robotics applications. The analysis identified **9 key entities** across the paper:

### Methods (2):
1. **Deep reinforcement learning** - The primary method being surveyed
2. **Neural network** - The core component combined with RL in deep RL

### Robotic Tasks/Competencies (7):
3. **Robotics** - The overall application domain
4. **Robot locomotion** - Movement and motion control
5. **Robot navigation** - Path planning and localization
6. **Manipulator** - Stationary manipulation tasks
7. **Mobile manipulator** - Integrated mobile and manipulation capabilities
8. **Human-robot interaction** - Safe collaboration between humans and robots
9. **Swarm robotics** - Multi-robot coordination and interaction

All triples have been validated with correct Wikipedia URLs and comprehensive relevance descriptions. The output file is ready for use in the knowledge graph pipeline.
